title: Understanding the Components
text: To determine the equilibrium temperature at which solid and liquid benzene coexist, you'll need to relate the molar enthalpy of fusion to the molar entropy of fusion.

title: Using Gibbs Free Energy
text: Recall that the Gibbs free energy change at equilibrium is zero. The equation ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - T ΔS can be rearranged to solve for T, where ΔH is the molar enthalpy and ΔS is the molar entropy.

title: Rearrange the Equation
text: Using the formula $$ΔG=ΔH-TΔS$$ , set ΔG to $$0$$ and solve for T.

title: Convert Units
text: Ensure that the units for enthalpy and entropy are consistent when calculating. Convert the molar entropy from $$\frac{J}{K·mol}$$ to $$\frac{kJ}{K·mol}$$ (1kJ $$=$$ 1000J).\n\n$$ΔS=\frac{35.7}{1000}$$ $$\frac{\pm kJ}{K} mol$$

title: Final Calculation
text: Now compute the equilibrium temperature using the rearranged equation with the consistent units.
